div1.p: The conference includes Noguchi, Flexner, White and Rose and involves yellow fever in West Africa.

div1.head: Minutes of a conference at the Rockefeller Institute, [19--]

p.hi:
Luncheon Conference - Rockefeller Institute -- Present: Doctor Flexner,
Doctor Noguchi, Doctor J H White and WR

list.item:
Recommendations of the yellow fever commission to West Africa were
read; the situation analyzed and the questions for consideration defined

(2) Concerning the question as to the probable menace of the infection
in Africa to the rest of the world, Doctor White stated with positive convic-
tion that the presence of the infection in Africa should be regarded as a seri-
ous menace so long as it exists; within his own experience he has had under ob-
servation a case of yellow fever brought from Africa across the Atlantic Ocean;
it is quite possible for it to travel by easy stages from the present infected
region in West Africa to Cape Town, up the East Coast and across to the Orient;
once introduced into the dense, non-immune populations of the Orient, its con-
trol would be practically impossible and the loss of life one would not care to
contemplate

(3) It was agreed that the final determination of the question as to whe-
ther the infection in Africa is yellow fever depends upon the application of
the Noguchi technic; the experience of the British commission appointed to sub-
mit a report on the question of yellow fever in West Africa is a ground for be-
lieving that the question cannot be determined upon the basis of clinical evi-
dence alone. If the Board should send another commission to Africa, it should
rely upon a competent personnel to apply the Noguchi technic under field condi-
tions

(4) Doctor Flexner and Doctor Noguchi agree that they should have about
twelve months for the thorough training of men for this work. Doctor Robinson
and Doctor Cross are now in training; after completing their laboratory work
with Doctor Noguchi, they are to be sent to the field with a view to acquiring
command of the technic under field conditions; their work thus far is promising.
Doctor Flexner advises that additional men be placed in training in order to
give opportunity for the selection of the best for the work in Africa

(5) Doctor White was given opportunity for a thorough examination of Doc-
tor Noguchi's material in his laboratory; the examination included specimens of
livers, hearts, lungs, stomachs, intestines, with microscopic examination of
tissues from these organs, from human and animal victims of Leptospira icteroides;
slides showing the organism embedded in human and animal tissues. After this
examination Doctor White expressed himself as convinced this material gives the
pathological picture of yellow fever

(6) Doctor Noguchi then exhibited a specimen given to him by Doctor Simp-
son; the specimen was taken from a man who died of yellow fever in New Orleans
in 1905; the specimen shows the spirochaete embedded in the tissue; this spiro-
chaete Doctor Simpson himself discovered at that time; Doctor White stated that
he had charge of the yellow fever epidemic in New Orleans at that time; that it
was one of the most severe epidemics New Orleans ever experienced; that there
could be no doubt as to its being yellow fever; that Doctor Simpson was working
-2-
under him when this specimen was secured; he regarded this as confirming the
other findings of Doctor Noguchi

(7) Out of this grew the suggestion that perhaps additional pathological
material may have been preserved in New Orleans from this and other yellow fe-
ver epidemics together with clinical histories of the cases; that Doctor Nogu-
chi will probably be able to secure this material for examination. Doctor White
is to take the matter up by correspondence with his friends in New Orleans; if
any other specimens should be found the cumulative evidence would have tremen-
dous weight
